positive.review:
I‚Äôve played Rust for over a thousand hours, but if you‚Äôre thinking of joining‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt. I‚Äôm writing this as a warning, not advice. Because Rust isn‚Äôt a game. It‚Äôs a place. And once you set foot on that island, a part of you stays there forever‚Äîusually the part that sleeps peacefully.

My first night in Rust, I built a tiny shack. Four walls, a door, a campfire. I felt safe. I shouldn‚Äôt have. Because in Rust, safety is just silence before the storm.

It started with footsteps. Soft, circling. Then a whisper in voice chat:
‚ÄúNice base you‚Äôve got.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt sleep much after that.

You learn quickly that everyone on the island is either a hunter or prey, and you don‚Äôt get to choose which one you are. You‚Äôll wake up to your base gone, your loot scattered, and a sign left behind saying something like ‚ÄúThanks :)‚Äù‚Äîbecause Rust players like to smile while they take everything from you.

You‚Äôll respawn naked. Again. And again. And again.

And then you‚Äôll start to change.

You‚Äôll begin to hear phantom footsteps even when you aren‚Äôt playing. You‚Äôll flinch at the sound of a helicopter. You‚Äôll see piles of rocks on the side of the road and feel an urge‚Äîan instinct‚Äîto hit them with something. Anything. You‚Äôll start checking bushes for movement. You‚Äôll judge every structure you pass in real life by whether it can withstand 12 rockets.

Rust does that to you.

And when you log in at 3AM just to ‚Äúcheck on your base,‚Äù you‚Äôll realize the truth:
You‚Äôre not playing Rust anymore. Rust is playing you.

So if you‚Äôre thinking of starting‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt.
Because once you load in, once you swing that first rock, once you hear the first distant gunshot echo through the trees‚Äî

there‚Äôs no coming back.
honestly shit game, im addicted to it and i hate it but i cant stop playing it.
Of all the animals, man is the only one that is cruel. He is the only one that inflicts pain for the pure pleasure of doing it," - Mark Twain.
Such a good game, I would never recommend it but its so good.
This game has its ups and downs. Spawn on beach naked get loot, die, do it all over. Hours make the difference.

Rust isn‚Äôt a game.
Rust is a lifestyle disease you willingly install.

The moment you spawn naked on the beach with nothing but a rock and crippling hope, the game whispers, ‚ÄúSay goodbye to your social life.‚Äù And you listen. Because you‚Äôre weak.

Rust consumes you slowly.
First, you think, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just farm a little wood.‚Äù
Ten hours later, you‚Äôre still hitting trees like a deranged lumberjack, staring at your screen with the same thousand-yard stare as someone who has seen too much.

You build a base. You love your base.
You name it. You tuck it in at night.
Then a group of 15 sweatlords shows up with rockets and deletes not just the base, but your will to live.

You log off to take a break.
You log back in to find your base gone, your loot stolen, and your soul spiritually repossessed by Chad, King of Oil Rig.

To get good at Rust, you must:

Ignore sleep

Forget weekends exist

Sacrifice friends, hobbies, and possibly grades

Train your aim until your wrist cries for mercy

Learn to accept betrayal as a natural weather phenomenon

Rust isn‚Äôt hard ‚Äî it‚Äôs emotionally expensive.

Every wipe feels like a fresh start and also a fresh mistake.
Every raid feels like a victory and also a sign that you‚Äôve gone too far to ever be normal again.

Rust doesn‚Äôt just suck your soul. It puts it in a small box, labels it ‚Äúloot,‚Äù and lets someone else take it while laughing in global chat.

10/10.
Would respawn naked on the beach again.

Every victory feels legendary, winning a 1v3 with 12 HP, finding a decayed base loaded with loot, or successfully cooking food without burning it like a caveman disaster. Every loss feels personal and emotionally damaging in ways that should probably be studied by scientists.
This game is so peak so many chances for hardcore players to have in game survival along with some of the best PvP I have ever experienced.
Fun game with frequent wipes which helps keeps things fresh

I've played this game on and off for many years and overall, I love it. I do have some positive and not as positive things to say about the current state of the game though

Positives: I love the game style, offering PvP and PvE content on different servers. This versatility is probably one of my most favorite thing about this game however the graphics have improved greatly over the years. Most holiday events are self explanatory to complete and the rewards are fairly good. The purchasable skins are also something I enjoy adding, and the cost of the items are reasonable, including purchases on the marketplace. Creatures in the game are challenging at the beginning of the wipe but once geared, are quite easy to defeat. Monuments are fun to explore and offer many hiding spots while participating in PvP. Over the years, they have added quite a bit of content and though I took breaks throughout the years, I would give Rust an overall positive rating. The environment is beautiful and the things they've done to improve the look has been phenomenal. On smaller servers, I've had the opportunity to create lifelong friends in other parts of the world, so I'd have to say this is probably my top favorite thing about this game.

Negatives: I believe too much has been added to the game and somewhat takes away from the original vanilla Rust from the mid 2010s. Some items have been nerfed quite a bit so it makes game play quite different while also giving larger groups advantages that smaller groups or solo players may not have. For new players, this makes the game undesirable. Friends I've invited to play Rust with me have stopped playing for this reason. Why play a game that's impossible to learn while getting defeated within minutes at respawn? Playing on a PvE server can be fun, but doesn't quite offer the challenges that a PvP server has. The addition of blueprints has been something that I believe would have been good in theory, but in practice offers larger groups to benefit from right out the gate. I understand the point of teaming up in a PvP environment, but there is no benefit to playing on a large server as a solo or even a small team for the first time. An issue I've experienced is sometimes while dismounting a horse, you'll get stuck or kicked for anticlip if the horse is beside another one at the trough. This is one of a few issues I've seen which I expected would've been fixed by now, but it still seems to be an issue. 

If you can ignore the negatives I've stated above, I still recommend this game. I play as often as possible and I've been playing again now for about a year. I've been officially playing Rust since about 2015 and it is still my favorite game despite the things I've listed as negatives. Happy hunting!
the equivalent of being shot by a firing squad. 11/10, this game is among the best
I think its a good game and very fun but I don't have any friends who play, it's really hard and it seems like it takes a long time to make progress.

This game is for people who have a lot of time 
If you are a casual player then it is not for you as your base will either decay or get raided
The only chance for you to play as a casual solo is to join PVE only servers
This game favours larger groups over solos

Regarding this game, you should know that the first and most important thing is that you are playing with other people whom you do not know much about, so while you should consider their mental and physical conditions and even the quality of their system, you should also pay attention to the issue of trusting an unknown person in exchange for your own efforts. Here, betrayal means losing all your efforts.
I suggest that you choose reliable teammates in every way, quality and harmony will increase over time, but trust once lost will never be regained, and this will make you distrust even good and new people. The second point is that this game requires a lot of time during the day to progress, so be careful not to let it hold you back from work and real life.

After more than 3,400 hours in Rust, I can honestly say:
I love this game. It‚Äôs brutal, unforgiving, and sometimes completely insane but that‚Äôs exactly what makes it special. Every wipe creates new stories you write yourself, new encounters, new chaos, and new memories.

The freedom Rust gives you is incredible. Every decision matters, every moment can turn into something unforgettable. I‚Äôve met so many people in this game, made friends, lost bases, won impossible fights and it never gets old.

On top of that, the developers have been pouring passion into Rust for years. The constant updates, improvements, and attention to detail show how much love goes into this world.

For me, Rust is simply one of the best games ever made.
I HATE THIS GAME I HATE THIS GAME I HATE THIS GAME I HATE THIS GAME I HATE THIS GAME... almost 1000 hours later.... I HATE THIS GAME I HATE THIS GAME
Build a 2x2 in the middle of no where, Eight man pull's up and blows open the base. Start again... Great game will play again.
Very cool game, but lacks beginner friendly features.

high skill ceiling, pve and pvp which i love 
lk reminds me of minecraft but realistic
love the modded servers
honestly a lot of stuff to do in game a lot of stuff to master
you can be as creative as you want with your base designs and traps
also idk why but i get clash of clans vibes but on pc and 1st person maybe its the clans or the base raiding or the satisfaction you get from getting loot
[tips for anyone wanting to buy the game] if you buy this game i recommend starting off in a low-pop server closest to your region then build your rust knowledge off of pure gameplay just so you dont get annoyed by the other players
best played in a group or solo if your a hardcore player

the worst game you can ever buy, dude in was just chilling and then a nuke dropped on my head

10/10
My most reluctant recommendation ever (perhaps only after Ark). But I mean, with almost 3k hours there's got to be something to like there, right? ....Right?!

Rust is the purest form of digital survival ever created. It drops you into the world naked, cold, confused, and holding a rock, which coincidentally is the same way most people start their freshman year of college.

From that moment on, the game drains your life energy in every direction. Hunger, thirst, radiation, temperature, other players, wolves, bears, and that one guy named ‚ÄúxXxToiletSniperxXx‚Äù who kills you the moment you craft your first pair of pants. Rust doesn‚Äôt just want you to survive. Rust wants you to suffer and maybe survive if it‚Äôs feeling generous.

The building system is great until someone raids you at 3 AM with enough explosives to qualify as a small military. Lose your base. Lose your loot. Lose your will to live. It is the full Rust experience.

Rust is brutal, hilarious, and best enjoyed with friends you can blame for everything. If you ever want to know what true survival feels like, Rust will teach you. It will also steal your lunch money while doing it.
Nice game, you can find anything you‚Äôre interested in, from PvP to farming and building a cozy base.

if you love playing games with friends this a good game. if you like to wake up pissed off sometimes this is the game for you. if your a grinder this is the game for you, i come from dayz and love this game as much as dayz. that says alot cause i love dayz so much.

Its not that good 1.2/10
 
anyway,

absolute peak player interactions and amazing pvp, exactly what I expected from valve, def recommend

it says i have 66 hours on record but i have 3000 actually. if you enjoy hard survival games and actually manage to build a base be ready for it to be destroyed in the next few hours after you hop off. also if you like getting jumped by 3 people with bows and spears this is the game for you

Rust is an amazing game, the developers are doing a great job of shuffling the meta, and changing progression to stop the game from being stale.
It s like "Minecraft" but very realistic and whit guns so its very fun.

Playing Rust feels like signing up for a vacation in a war-torn sandbox where the only amenities are fear and emotional damage. Every login is a fresh opportunity to be touched un-consensually by the players of Rust, as if the entire server collectively agreed I‚Äôm the designated victim. I can‚Äôt even enjoy thirty seconds of peace before being heartlessly Double-Barreled while farming materials as I spawn in, still blinking sand out of my eyes as I spawn on the beach, naked and alone, pretending hope exists. And yet, despite the trauma, the betrayal, and the lingering scent of burning hemp fibers, I proudly give Rust a 10 star rating, because apparently I love the game I hate more than my enemies love offline raiding me.

Just for reference I've played this game a lot more on other platforms. I'm so impressed at how Rust is not only surviving, but thriving on it's way into the future! Even all these years later...

After the downfall of Ark Survival: Evolved I needed somewhere to get my PVP survival crafting fix and the Rust community was waiting for me with open arms, a dumb toothy grin, and a knife behind their back. 10/10 would do it all over again!
dont go for loot, theres only a little fun in that. instead make everyone else's experience of the game abysmal, only then will you reach peak rust

controversial recent changes aside that i hate the game is good and funny. new player experience sucks ass, as it should.

Rust is an awesome survival game ‚Äî fun with friends, great for meeting new people on PvE servers, and full of chaos in PvP. You can build, explore, and survive together‚Ä¶ or raid others and destroy their bases for loot. Every session feels different and exciting!

My first night in Rust, I built a tiny shack. Four walls, a door, a campfire. I felt safe. I shouldn‚Äôt have. Because in Rust, safety is just silence before the storm.

It started with footsteps. Soft, circling. Then a whisper in voice chat:
‚ÄúNice base you‚Äôve got.‚Äù

You learn quickly that everyone on the island is either a hunter or prey, and you don‚Äôt get to choose which one you are. i like the game but i got vac banned for doing a glich by spamming a button that resets you graphics or somthing and it makes you fly if you jump and do it
The game is very clear about what it is. Trust nobody, kill for the best loot. Monuments are fun, combat is fun. Makes my PC run like a snail. 11/10

The greatest PVP survival game on the market right now.

The learning curve is steep, but trust me, it‚Äôs absolutely worth it! The early game can feel punishing, and I think that‚Äôs where a lot of players drop off before giving it a fair shot. Stick with it, though, and like most things, persistence pays off and you‚Äôll end up hooked.

From a developer standpoint, the support is fantastic. Updates aren‚Äôt just tiny bug fixes or overhyped tweaks, they‚Äôre meaningful improvements that actually matter. We‚Äôre talking quality-of-life changes, fresh content, and regular meta shake-ups to keep things exciting. New biomes, vehicles, weapons ‚Äî all designed to prevent the game from ever feeling stale.

The community is, for the most part, great. Sure, the ‚Äúsurvival of the fittest‚Äù and ‚Äúevery man for himself‚Äù mentality shines through at times, but honestly, that only adds to the immersion. It feels like a true survival experience where PVE and PVP blend seamlessly.

Base building? Phenomenal. Whether you‚Äôre crafting a sprawling fortress or a humble 2x2 shack, the options are nearly endless. Add in the community-driven side of server ownership and customization, and you‚Äôve got a game that feels limitless in how you can play.

If survival/PVP/base building and crafting is your genre, this is the game for you.
Besides the hours on top of hours just to be graped by some zerg and get offlined, this game is great for other players! If you like being touched on your butt by a zerg, I double suggest this game!

A Brutal and unforgiving open world survival game.  Skill and Decent Pc Specs Not included

The game offers endless fun, from building and fighting to farming and even caring for animals, with all the details connecting these elements. Furthermore, in-game purchases are limited to skins only; there are no items that, when purchased, give a player an advantage in winning or progressing through the game. It's worth noting that these packages are quite expensive and can even cost as much as the game itself (lol). Finally, the game studio's support for multiple languages is noteworthy.

The only downside to the game is the general perception of its players, which is, of course, true: all players are untrustworthy, and treachery is common in the game (lol).
Apart from the unavoidable offline raids this game is a blast especially with friends. New updates every month keeps things fresh and I am a sucker for building and decorating lol

Welcome to Wust.

This isn‚Äôt just a game. It‚Äôs a chaotic ritual. A place where logic dies the moment someone shows up with a box of Twinkies, a warm bottle of Mountain Dew and a questionable squeeze of mustard. Mix those three together and Wust stops being entertainment. It becomes something else. Something louder. Something dumber. Something legendary.

Every match feels like it crawled out of a fever dream someone had at 3am after eating too much sugar. Physics doesn‚Äôt behave. Players make choices scientists would refuse to study. And somehow, all of it comes together into an experience that crushes every piece of fiction, media or game mankind has ever put out.

If you‚Äôre here, buckle up. Wust isn‚Äôt played. Wust is survived.
pretty goated game genuinly all the hate is from people whove never played so anyone reading this should give it a try and then ill respect your opinion

Would 100% reccomend

negative.review: With the latest update including having to acquire Blueprint fragments, it makes it nearly impossible to play as a solo player. Such a huge disappointment. It also encourages those in larger clans to build near high tier monuments just to pick off the poor solo or duo players just trying to get BP frags just to get a Tier 3 workbench. Such a bad update. Its not encouraging me whatsoever to run the monuments when there's only a 10 percent chance that I'll even get an advanced BP frag. Do better FacePunch and stop wasting our time.

my most played game but also one of my least favorites because it's like being in an infinite dopamine loop. I could've been a successful goose farmer by now but instead I have anhedonia and a less functional prefrontal cortex.

No linux support. Read PC Gamer article about how they said games that support Linux are not "serious about anti-cheat", which is a joke, because Rust has some of the worst cheaters of any game. I am moving to Linux so I will not be buying or playing any of their games ever again. I was sick of Rust anyway but you deserve this bad review for being full of shit and for the guns in Rust still feeling like ASS after 10 years. Git gud. Linux is the FUTURE of gaming, Gabe wills it and Gabe has spoken. Fuck around and find out.

Unfair False Positive Ban ‚Äì Completely Frustrating

I‚Äôve been a dedicated Rust player, but my experience has been ruined by a false positive temporary gameban. I have never used cheats, scripts, or any unauthorized software, yet I was banned from all servers. This wasn‚Äôt due to anything I did, but apparently due to ‚Äúabnormal activity‚Äù or playing on a server with cheaters ‚Äî something completely beyond my control.

The support team eventually responded, but these automatic bans are overly aggressive and extremely frustrating for legitimate players. Being locked out of a game I‚Äôve invested in, through no fault of my own, is completely unacceptable.

Facepunch needs to seriously improve their ban detection system and provide faster, more transparent resolution. As it stands, their system punishes innocent players while leaving cheaters often unaffected. This experience has made me reconsider continuing with Rust.
This game makes me nut uncontrollably, its not healthy to nut 20 times per hour

I love this game, I got 6k plus hours. And because I love it I have to give it a bad review after the latest scrap updates. It is non sense, kills the game. No more survival aspect. Starting to look more like a battlefield than a survival type game. Solo experience has been degrading for as long as I can remember, and this last update killed it. This is the first game I‚Äôve ever reviewed.
And instead of writing another ‚Äúfunny Rust moment,‚Äù I want to be honest ‚Äî because if you‚Äôre thinking about buying Rust, you should know what it actually feels like.

Rust is not a survival game anymore. It‚Äôs a full-time job simulator.
If you don‚Äôt play constantly, you fall behind.
You become weaker, you become walking loot, and your base disappears the moment you decide to sleep like a normal person.

And the biggest issue becomes obvious very quickly: Rust is built for groups.
If you enjoy playing solo, chilling, exploring, or playing a reasonable 3‚Äì4 hours a day (which is not a small amount), the game punishes you for it.
Everything becomes unfair the moment you join the server.
Teams dominate the wipe before you even place your second door.

Every update seems to make solo players weaker.
And the newest one ‚Äî blueprint fragment changes ‚Äî affects small groups and solo players far more than teams. Bigger groups barely notice it, but for solos it slows progression even more.

So playing solo becomes something that barely counts as playing.
Avoid every fight unless it‚Äôs another unlucky solo, set your base where nobody wants to live, hide from every sound, and deliver free loot to 5-man teams at monuments when you‚Äôre just trying to get a blueprint.

I remember one wipe where I spent almost 4 hours stuck in primitive just because I joined the wipe 30 minutes late. Teams already had revolvers and other guns, and even with perfect aim there was no realistic way to win a fight. That‚Äôs the true solo Rust experience.

And what‚Äôs the ‚Äúsolution‚Äù people offer?
Go play low-pop or PVE servers. Which is basically the equivalent of going to an amusement park and, instead of riding the roller coaster, sitting on the tiny kids‚Äô train and pretending you‚Äôre having the same experience.
So you‚Äôre telling me the only way I can enjoy Rust‚Ä¶ is by not playing Rust?

Instead of improving, you end up searching for bigger groups, staying awake until 5 AM to save a base that shouldn‚Äôt require night shifts to protect.

this game is more fun to watch than it is to play.
Streamers make it look amazing because they have thousands of hours, stacked teammates, gifted skins, and unlimited time. With that combination, any game would look incredible.

And optimization isn‚Äôt any better. Rust runs like a jet engine attached to a bicycle.
Unity is old, and the game has been duct-taped together for ten years instead of being rebuilt properly, so even high-end PCs drop FPS for absolutely no reason.
A stable 80+ FPS is a fantasy for most players.

I genuinely loved this game.
It‚Äôs one of the reasons I even bought a PC.
And Rust could have been one of the greatest survival games ever made.
But at some point, Rust completely shifted its identity into what it is now.

Early Rust was magical. Discovery mattered. Solo was possible. Time investment wasn‚Äôt insane.
Now nothing feels in the right place ‚Äî and I honestly regret that I never got to experience that era. I arrived too late.

So congratulations, Facepunch. You‚Äôre losing the chill players.
What will you gain?

An insane amount of 50-IQ players and below,
Massive clans,
No-life grinders,
Cheaters with endless alt accounts,
But it‚Äôs all good for you ‚Äî more people to buy your P2W skins!

Many players still grind Rust mindlessly, chasing tiny dopamine hits without realizing what they‚Äôre sacrificing.
At least I figured it out. I‚Äôm giving myself a long, long break.

Every update they put out makes it harder to play as a solo/duo. The latest changes to workbench crafting is yet another example.

I absolutely love the concept of this game, but recent updates by the developers don't make sense and are lackluster, I believe this game is being mismanaged.

**jungle update**
  - doesn't make sense gameplay-wise, tier 0 biome right next to spawn beach yet has wildly unfair animal AI compared to other biomes
  - doesn't offer any monuments other than ziggarat, it looks cool, but offers almost nothing for the amount of risk you have to go through.
**meta shift**
  - slows down progression (people complained that it's too fast) by adding blueprint fragments to various puzzles
  - kind of works on low pop, a lot of players from my server complain that it's not fun to obtain
  - you will be prim-locked forever as a solo / small team on high pop.
  - fragments serve no purpose afterwards if you already have the corresponding workbench
  - imo they tackled the wrong thing, they should've done something about unlocks, not workbenches
**pivot or die**
  - made tech tree costs stupidly low (why? didn't you just slow down progression?)
  - removed workbench taxes by default (this is something that i believe should've been experimented with, reward players for finding items in-world with noticeable cost reductions, rather than completely locking them out of workbenches and then suddenly making lucky players with workbenches be able to progress at mach 4)
**naval update**
  - not out, but so far from staging branch seems like it'll have the same issue like the jungle biome where there's not enough value for the amount of effort and risk you have to go through to reach and stay afloat in the deep sea

it just seems like they're changing stuff just for the sake of change and that they've ran out of ideas. although i've never played during this era, i believe that rust's content updates had more vision under Garry's leadership. every update served a purpose whereas a lot of newer updates under Alistair's leadership don't add anything interesting or even actively harm the game. there's also been a lot more focus on monetization to the point where I feel like I'm playing a F2P game, P2W items exist, they allow you to do things normal players can't do, there is literally a hazmat that changes stats for money. servers owners also lose a lot of control over their own servers with new EULA changes, you cannot even the odds between players by giving P2W items in any way (loot tables, ability to craft, etc) as a server owner, you cannot restrict players with P2W items from using them for any reason at all either, it's not a good look and just sucks for people who dislike having to spend money on microtransactions to compete on a game that's they've already paid for.

optimization is also another issue, it uses an absurd amount of VRAM (6GB for eighth resolution, which is the lowest graphics preset) for a game that doesn't look as good as others which consume less memory, this could be a unity limitation for all i know but this is absurd and it was never this bad when i played a year ago. it also uses a ton of memory in general and 16GBs is not something you should be playing with. recent updates have also added a lot of buggy code and constant client errors which aren't seemingly being addressed.

i also want to express my concerns about Linux support, as it would be really nice if you allowed EAC to work under Proton, it's a single checkbox that you can tick in the EOS dashboard and shipping linux EAC binaries. I know it's weaker but would it be that bad considering that most servers already moderate suspicious players? It won't stop me from playing as I've created a non-EAC server alongside a friend that's marginally successful, but it would be a nice gesture from Facepunch.

you've created an awesome game that I personally enjoy, there's nothing like it anywhere else in the entire game's industry but it has so many flaws that I cannot recommend it to new-comers in this state.

Isn't at all the game the game I purchased when it first come out, haven't played it in many many years, and never will. This is another game that belongs on my list of regretful purchases, I was younger and a lot dumber back then.

Honestly, it's a good game.  The thing is ; the experience can either be really good or really bad. I've certainly had good fun on this game, and i can see how so many people play this game. I can't see myself really recommending this game to anyone who is not a hardcore gamer. If you truly want to get good at the game, you have to poor hours and hours because other people put in their hours.  It's definitely NOT a beginner friendly game and i do not recommend playing this game blind for the first time with ought having an experienced friend to play with.

I do understand however that it is a fun game. If you are ready to put in the hours, and get better, then i would recommend it. You can have fun interactions with other players and even make some friends. A big portion of Rust's player base is not so friendly, and will get mad at you even if you have done nothing wrong. KOS is also something people do, being kill on sight, so going in be prepared for that.

Other then that, the base game is fun, the graphics are pretty good and the progression feels well balanced especially with new updates that force you to go to monuments, witch in turn forces player fights, and requires a higher level of skill.

All in all, i do think it's a fun game. I've had good experiences with it but i can't find myself recommending it to anyone. If you want to give it a shot, by all means, go for it. Just keep in minds the things I've said - as you might get pretty frustrated at first. Hope this review helped - and have a good day.

Rust ‚Äî The Game That Forgot What Survival Means

I‚Äôve got a ridiculous number of hours in this god-forsaken game, and honestly, it just keeps getting worse. I‚Äôve seen Rust through every era ‚Äî from legacy pits to the current ‚Äúbattle royale with extra steps.‚Äù

Every wipe is the same: join a server, build a base, run around collecting junk , and sooner or later you run into a giant clan or a cheater who guns you down like a dog. Then you start over, because that‚Äôs Rust, right? Grind, raid, rebuild, repeat‚Ä¶ until the server dies with 20 people left.

The (recoil rework) killed solo skill. You can‚Äôt outplay clans anymore, you just avoid their zones and hope. The blueprint system had potential, but the latest patch ruined it. Big groups hit one cargo run and have AKs, rockets, and launchers within an hour of wipe. Progression‚Äôs gone, balance is gone.

My Fixes

* Bring back real blueprints ‚Äî you should (need a blueprint fragment to craft any gun)
* Fragments come in three tiers (*small, medium, large*) 
* Guns should require fragments:

  * Tier-2 guns ‚Üí 1 fragment
  * Tier-3 guns ‚Üí 5 fragments
* Blueprints fragments drop in about 20% of boxes and scientists .
* Move rockets and launchers to Tier-3 bench only.
* Delay cargo ships and locked crate events for the first 24 h after wipe.
* Excavators? Scrap them ‚Äî they‚Äôre just clan property at this point.
* Add drone shops where you can buy items anywhere on the map (but no protection , if you get caught, good luck).
* Give solos a chance ‚Äî small caves or mini-monuments where they can actually build and survive.

I don‚Äôt speak for any community  just a long-time player who‚Äôs seen it all. Rust used to be brutal but fair. Now it‚Äôs just exhausting.

I have more than three thousand hours in Rust and for a long time it was my go to game. I loved the grind, the suspense of roaming with a full inventory, the rush of winning or losing a fight that actually mattered. It was brutal, but it felt fair most of the time, and the progression from primitive to late game was one of the most satisfying parts of the experience.

The recent changes to the workbench and blueprints completely killed that feeling for me. Progression used to feel like something you earned through smart decisions, good fights, and efficient farming. Now it feels like a chore and a punishment. The way you unlock and access items does not feel rewarding at all. It drags out the grind, takes away a lot of the creativity in how you progress a wipe, and makes every restart feel like the same boring checklist instead of a fresh run with new opportunities.

I can handle Rust being hard. I can handle getting offline raided, roof camped, or zerged. That is all part of the chaos that makes the game memorable. What I cannot be bothered with is a progression system that feels like it is fighting me every step of the way. Right now it just feels clunky, restrictive, and honestly not fun. Instead of thinking about cool plays or new base ideas, I find myself thinking about how annoying it is to deal with the workbench and unlock system again.

At this point I will be spending my time in Battlefield 6. I never thought I would say that, but Rust in its current state is just not it. Hopefully the devs actually listen and rethink these changes, because under all this mess there is still an incredible game. As it stands though, the game is fucking horrible and it is a thumbs down from me.

I want to recommend this game so badly. The core gameplay loop is addictive and satisfying, easily one of the best in the genre. However, the cheating problem has made it completely unplayable.

As a legitimate player, you accept that you might lose your gear to a better player, that's part of the game. But losing hours of farming and intricate building to someone using ESP who raids you in less than a minute? That isn't losing; that's being robbed of your time.

Running around for 10 minutes trying to just get started  and establish...anything. to get killed and start all over again. I guess if you started the game when it first dropped it is OK, but heaven help anybody who tries it out now. An exercise in futility is the best I can describe it. Wasted money. only played for 7 hours total and asked for a refund. Nothing.

Its a fun game. But if they are unwilling to support Linux/Proton, then I cant support this game. Windows is falling. It sucks. Of you cant figure out how to work an anti cheat on linux... well id say that says more about the devs than anyone else. Reading that article where the devs said 'games that support linux/Proton arnt serious about anticheat' makes me actually want to refund this. I wish I could take my money back if I had known the devs had this kind of thought process. If I cant vote with my wallet on this one, ill vote with my presence. I wont be playing this game again unless it gets support on Linux or Proton. And if it never does, I guess youll never see me in the player count for this game. So be it.

I see the appeal for people who grind, maybe I just had a bad experience but:
Had this game since 2017 or 2018 I think but couldn't run this game for absolute ages which had already gave me a bad view on this game but then again my PC was ass.
But when I was able to run this game, yeah it was fun with mates (couldn't imagine playing solo, it's not my type of game tbh it's a lot of external learning) and we played for a few hours, got a base, the whack and then had guns. Went on a few expeditions to gather loot but there was like nobody there which is fine because free loot but I'm pure bravo 6ing the place out because I'm ass at the game. We get the loot, we get the setup, we're chilling for a while then get destroyed on our next expedition from a roof, rinse and repeat. 
Had this loop for around 50 hours tbh my playtime is inaccurate because most of my hours would be from my old PC and loading the game for a solid 30-40 minutes, crashing or getting in then crashing and repeating this cycle LOL.
The only joy I get is setting up base and whatnot but then after that it's when I kill nakeds but that makes me feel evil deep down because they are helpless, yet I am helpless against these roof campers.
Maybe I could recommend trolling for fun or joining a 10x server would be fun because it's chaotic.
But for Vanilla or like modded 2x/3x servers, pretend everyone is the same skill level in the game starting from wipe, it's a game of who has their PC on longer / grinds more in my opinion because I don't see a goal.
Rather play CS.

Absolutely loved this game, having spent over 2000 hours in game so far. BUT, the most recent progression changes are biased against solos ( of which I'm one), and unless you spend your life in game ( yes, I know they exist) you will never keep pace with groups and will always be fodder. Having to do an uphill slog with blueprints every month only to be a victim very quickly each wipe isnt fun. ( its also not fun finding that all the BP's you have unlocked on your favorite servers have gone, and if you want to play on various servers you have to multiply the grind). Perhaps the developers are no longer interested in solos or that their goal is that solos are only team fodder, but just be honest. I wont be dumping the game completely, but it will no longer be an every month play - just perhaps a now and again. Also, thats the end of my skin purchases.

Imagine you want to play Rust for the first time. After you build the Workbench Level 1 your progression stopped. The blueprint fragments are hard to get. Those are available at monuments which are contested by groups.
Farming in the ocean became useless because you are not getting any blueprint fragments there and you are stuck at some point.
